oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Ben Reitman and associates
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Part of a collection of materials relating to physician and reformer Benjamin Reitman, founder of Hobo College, this photograph likely depicts one of the classrooms where migratory workers passing through Chicago obtained practical and academic educational experience.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituary for Gustav Massman, 1985
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: Kenan Heise, Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gustav Massman was a longtime bridge tender in Chicago. For many years, he was in charge of the Halsted Street Bridge on Goose Island. His obituary offers a glimpse of life as a bridge tender in twentieth-century Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Advertisement for D. S. Taylor Property, c. 1873
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cartographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Real estate developers made speculative subdivisions of land around the Calumet River following the completion of federal government improvements in 1871. D. S. Taylor's subdivisions along the east side of the Calumet River shows the growing interest in the Calumet region by 1874. Slips and wharves along the Calumet River, as well as adjacent railroads, provided excellent transportation for industry and trade.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Great Goose Island Expedition," 1930
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: John Drury, Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Drury's Map of Goose Island was first published on March 26, 1930, in the Chicago Daily News. The map shows the location of Goose Island on Chicagos Near North Side, located between Chicago and North Avenues. Division Street runs across the middle of the island, which was formed after the dredging of the North Branch (Ogden) Canal. While this is a fanciful representation, the map does show the concentration of housing on North Branch, Cherry, and Hickory Streets south of Division Street. The foot of the island was home to shipyards, lumber yards, coal yards, and grain elevators.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Begin Final Link of Ogden Avenue Drive This Week," 1934
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The improvement of Ogden Avenue was part of a citywide highway upgrade that emerged after the recommendations of the Burnham Plan of 1909. In late 1934, the completion of ramps to the Ogden Avenue viaduct connected Goose Island businesses to that "fast arterial highway," as described in this Chicago Tribune article from November 26, 1934. The photograph shows the Hickory Street Ramp to the Ogden Avenue Viaduct in 1989. The orientation was no longer to the river and canal, but to new limited access highways. Goose Island would be even more closely connected to expressways with the opening of the adjacent Kennedy Expressway in 1960, giving it a strategic location advantage in the age of truck and air freight. Among the companies that had moved to Goose Island by the 1970s were Charles Levy Circulating Company and Chicago Terminal Clearance, a large trucking operation that specialized in piggyback car loadings

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Goose Island," 1885
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Philip Armour sought to control all aspects of the grain trade, from purchase to transport to storage to ultimate sale in order to control costs at his packinghouses and as a means of controlling the lucrative grain trade. To that end, the first grain elevators on Goose Island were built in 1887 by the Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul Railroad (of which Armour was an major investor) to hold grain brought into Chicago from its north/northwest hinterland.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Matter for Financiers," 1887
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Philip Armour sought to control all aspects of the grain trade, from purchase to transport to storage to ultimate sale in order to control costs at his packinghouses and as a means of controlling the lucrative grain trade. To that end, the first grain elevators on Goose Island were built in 1887 by the Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul Railroad (of which Armour was an major investor) to hold grain brought into Chicago from its north/northwest hinterland.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Lets More Grain Go," 1897
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Philip Armour used his tremendous grain storage capacity on Goose Island and across the country to break another attempted corner on the wheat market in 1897-98. His adversary in 1897 was Joseph Leiter, the son of Levi Z. Leiter, a successful Chicago merchant. Armour even hired tugboats to keep the water open in the Duluth harbor until grain vessels could bring the wheat to Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Crash in Leiter Deal," 1898
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Philip Armour used his tremendous grain storage capacity on Goose Island and across the country to break another attempted corner on the wheat market in 1897-98. His adversary in 1897 was Joseph Leiter, the son of Levi Z. Leiter, a successful Chicago merchant. Armour even hired tugboats to keep the water open in the Duluth harbor until grain vessels could bring the wheat to Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Report of the Board of Health, 1849
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Journal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Levi D. Boone, Health Officer and Physician for Chicago, reported in the August 27, 1849 issue of the Chicago Journal, on his work with indigent cholera patients and those taken to the Cholera Hospital. Over half the indigent patients were Norwegians, most of whom lived in dense squatter settlements along the Chicago River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Cholera and Aurora," 1849
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Journal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cholera affected other communities in the Chicago area, including Aurora to the west along the Fox River. The experiences of Aurora residents were reported in the August 27, 1849 Chicago Journal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Advertisements for Cholera Remedies, 1849
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creators: Various
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The June 7, 1849 issue of the Chicago Democrat included several advertisements for cholera remedies. Since the bacterial origins of cholera would not be identified until the 1880s, the various cures had little medicinal worth.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Official Rules Polio Epidemic Stage Reached," 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On September 13, 1952, the Chicago Tribune reported that more than seven hundred people had contracted polio already that year, making it officially at epidemic stage. The Tribune health editor made a series of recommendations for rules during the polio epidemic.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Free Lake Baths for the Poor," 1892
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: Sarah Hackett Stevenson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1892 Sarah Hackett Stevenson, one of Chicago's most accomplished and respected women doctors, was the chair of the new Municipal Order League's Committee on Public Baths. The League, composed of primarily women, was formed to address the unsanitary conditions that existed throughout much of the city. It initiated a campaign to secure bathing facilities for the city's poor. As chair, Dr. Stevenson appealed to the Mayor to assist in opening the beaches of Lake Michigan to the public.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kimball and Lawrence Avenues, 1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Like many Chicago neighborhoods, the northwest Albany Park Community Area experienced a population explosion during the 1870s and 1880s. The completion of the Ravenswood Elevated line in 1907 further fueled the building boom, particularly around the station near the corner of Lawrence and Kimball Avenues.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: near Lawrence St. and Kimball Ave.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Students and faculty at the Institute of Design, c.1950
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Ray Pearson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chicago's Institute of Design, founded in 1937 as the New Bauhaus, served along with the Art Institute, Chicago Society of Arts and Crafts, and the Arts Club as an important center in the education of the city's and the nation's artists. Although its early reputation hinged on its photography program, it was equally regarded for its design curriculum, making Chicago an important center of industrial art and design.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Intersection of E. 79th St., S. Chicago and S. Stony Island Aves., 1953
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographers: Lil and Al Bloom
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Intersection of E. 79th St., S. Chicago and S. Stony Island Aves., 1953
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: E. 79th St., S. Chicago and S. Stony Island Aves.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: East on W. 103rd Street from S. Longwood Drive, 1908
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This 1908 photograph of the home of real estate dealer Robert C. Givins on S. Longwood Drive -- running near a glacial ridge that measures the highest point in Chicago -- reveals the spacious residences and tree-lined streets that made the community of Beverly a desirable location for Chicagoans seeking a suburban setting within city boundaries.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: South Longwood Drive and West 103rd Street

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Borg-Warner Corp., 1958
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Hubert Henry, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Borg-Warner Corp.'s headquarters on S. Michigan Ave. and E. Adams St., 1958

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Striking Illinois Central Railroad Workers in Burnside, 1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chicago's smallest community area, Burnside, is bounded on all sides by railroad tracks. During the first half of the twentieth century, railroads not only dominated Burnside's landscape, but also the lives of its residents, many of whom worked for the lines. In 1911, striking workers gathered along a railroad platform in Burnside during their labor action against the Illinois Central Railroad.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Butler Bros. Building, 1928
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Like Chicago's other significant mail-order businesses, Butler Bros. operated out of large warehouse facilities located near transportation corridors, as seen in this 1928 photo of the Butler Bros. site along the Chicago River in the Near West Side.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cracker Jack Co. Plant, 1958
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: William S. Engdahl, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The carmalized popcorn and peanuts produced in this Cracker Jack factory at 4800 W. 66th Street, along with confections produced by E. J. Brach, Tootsie Roll Industries, Wrigley Co., Curtiss Candy Co., Blommer Chocolate Company, and others, helped to define Chicago as a national center for candy production.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crate & Barrel Store, 1968
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: William S. Engdahl, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Original Crate & Barrel store at 1510 N. Wells Street in the Old Town neighborhood, 1968

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Interior of Dominick's Supermarket, 1962
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: William S. Engdahl, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dominick's supermarket at Dempster and Greenwood Streets in Park Ridge, 1962

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Testing Hair Dye at the Alberto-Culver Company Plant, 1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Robert H. Harr, Hedrich-Blessing

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Redlining: Discrimination in Residential Mortgage Loans (cover), 1975
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Illinois General Assembly, Legislative Investigating Commission
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Illinois Legislative Investigating Commission published its report in May 1975 after hearing allegations from individuals and civic groups, unsatisfied with current federal laws against redlining and frustrated by Illinois banks and savings and loans that continued to discriminate against mortgage-seekers in racially integrated areas of Chicago. The cover of their report replicated the color-coded maps that had been used by government agencies and financial institutions to denote neighborhoods that were supposedly high risk for lending and insurance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Standard Oil Refinery, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Opened in 1889, the Standard Oil refinery in Whiting, Indiana was one of the company's largest and most productive. In 1982, Standard Oil of Indiana refineries produced 1.2 million barrels of gasoline daily and served 18,000 domestic gasoline retail outlets. That year Standard's two largest refineries were located in Whiting and Texas City, Texas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Salvation Army Meeting, 1902
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The signs on the back wall of this Salvation Army meeting, held on December 24, 1902, reflect the evangelism associated with the organization during its early years in Chicago. A police officer stands in the foreground.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sandburg Village, 1964
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Calvin Hutchinson Photography
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In May 1956, in an effort to convince the Chicago Land Clearance Commission to allow for the redevelopment of the Near North Side, the North-LaSalle Site Designation Redevelopment Project presennted a report to the commission outlining the housing conditions that existed on the site south of North Avenue on Clark Street. The report found that 99.7% of the 2,418 living units lacked essential sanitation facilities, ventilation and lighting, and were largely overcrowded. The conclusions of the report led to the Commission's decision to allow for the private development of Sandburg Village, with rents well out of reach of former area residents.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effects of a Tornado along the Fox River in Elgin, 1920
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On March 28, 1920, tornadoes touched down in Chicago, Elgin, and the western suburbs, killing twenty three people and causing $1.5 million in damages. Several homes and businesses in downtown Elgin, including the Opera House and Grant Theater, were destroyed by the storm. Four Elgin residents were killed when the roofs of the First Congregational and First Baptist churches collapsed during Sunday services.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago Women's Liberation Union members, 1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Elaine Wessel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Chicago Women's Liberation Union (CWLU) march in the International Women's Day Demonstration in Chicago on March 9, 1974.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unveiling of Logan monument, 1897
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: George E. Mellen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1897, the State of Illinois and the City of Chicago commissioned American sculptor Augustus Saint Gaudens and A. Phimister Proctor to create a statue commemorating the military and political career of John A. Logan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: West Exchange Operating Room of the Chicago Telephone Company, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Switchboard operators direct calls at the Chicago Telephone Company's West Exchange Operating Room. Boys operated the first crude switchboards brought to Chicago by the Illinois Telephone Company in 1877. In 1878 Isabel Maunsell was hired by Bell Company as the first female switchboard operator.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Camping in the Forest Preserve in Forest Glen, 1922
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Raymond Hilliard Center, 1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Robert H. Harr, Bertrand Goldberg Associates
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Raymond Hilliard Center, designed by Bertrand Goldberg Associates, 1966

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Northwest at Irving Park Rd., Cicero Ave., and Milwaukee Ave., 1953
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Benar Studio
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Located on the border of the Portage Park and Irving Park neighborhoods on the city's northwest side, this intersection known as six corners was home to a thriving business district in 1953.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maxwell Street Market, 1917
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: According to the text written on the negative of this photograph taken by the Chicago Daily News staff, Maxwell Street was the "Chicago ghetto" in 1917.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Housing Development in Park Forest, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Owen Kent
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This 1952 aerial view of a Park Forest neighborhood captures the neat rows of homes that characterized the post-World War II housing boom in the planned community.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Circle Interchange Looking North, 1973
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Kennedy expressway runs north of the Circle Interchange and can be seen at the top of the photograph. The Ryan expressway reaches south at the bottom, the Eisenhower to the west, and Congress Parkway runs east from the Circle into city streets just south of the Loop. The University of Illinois's Chicago campus, once known as Circle Campus for its proximity to the traffic landmark, can be seen in the lower left corner of the photo.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Birdcage Parking Garage, 1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: J. Sherwin Murphy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The view west at the multi-story parking structure on the corner of State Street and Wacker Drive shows one of the strategies for handling increased automobile traffic in downtown Chicago during the mid-twentieth century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lasting Effects of Snowstorm, 1967
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Howard B. Anderson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: California Avenue between Rosemont and Granville Streets looking north on Sunday, January 28, 1967, three days after 23 inches of snow fell on Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Woodlawn Organization (TWO), 1963
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bishop Arthur Brazier with Woodlawn Organization (TWO) members Rosa Scott and Mary Booth outside TWO headquarters, April 25, 1963. Bishop Brazier of the Apostolic Church of God on Chicago's South Side cofounded TWO in 1960.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Zenith Radio store, 1936
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Philip B. Maher, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Console radio units are displayed in model living rooms in two illuminated, floor-to-ceiling windows of this Zenith Radio store in Chicago in September 1936. Personal radio purchases increased after the passage of the Rural Electrification Act in 1936, which coincided with a drop in radio prices and increased sales for the Chicago company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: O'Leary's on South Halsted Street, 1906
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The commercial center of largely Irish Canaryville in the early twentieth century was Halsted Street, which boasted saloons and gambling houses such as O'Leary's. Located just east of the Union Stock Yard, many of the area's customers were affiliated with the meatpacking industry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stateville Prison in Joliet, 1992
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Lloyd DeGrane
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stateville Prison opened in 1925 with the capacity to house 1,506 inmates. Originally designed by criminologist Jeremy Bentham as a panopticon cell house, the structure was commonly known as a "roundhouse" that featured an armed tower in the center of an open area surrounded by cells. Pictured here in 1992, Stateville has the only remaining "roundhouse" still in use in the United States.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Juvenile Court Committee Flier, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Juvenile Court Committee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Women reformers who had organized and led the movement for the founding of the Cook County Juvenile Court in 1899 subsequently formed the Juvenile Court Committee to raise money to provide probation officers and support the court's operations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Celebration of Obon, 1963
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Albert M. Hayashi
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Japanese Americans celebrated the Buddhist season of Obon (the season of gathering joy) with a parade in Chicago's Old Town area in July 1963. Featured here is an Obon dance group marching with members of Boy Scout Troop 74.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: 1763 N. North Park Ave. [CONFIRM: OLD TOWN]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blue Note Jazz Club, c.1950s
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Blue Note, one of Chicago's premiere jazz clubs during the 1950s, showcased nationally renowned musicians as regular acts, including Count Basie, Duke Ellington, and Benny Goodman.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Fitzpatrick, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Fitzpatrick, president of the Chicago Federation of Labor, is pictured here addressing workers on the south side of Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Junior League of Chicago, 1932
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members Dorothy Dewes, Mrs. Roger White, Margaret Hamill, and Anne Byron Smith pose with sacks used in their second-hand clothing drive to aid those who were less fortunate during the Great Depression in 1932.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dinner with Mayor Edward J. Kelly, 1938
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seated with Mayor Edward J. Kelly (middle) at a black-tie event on December 12, 1938 are Illinois Commerce Commission Chair James Michael Slattery (seated left), 31st Ward Alderman Thomas Keane (standing right), and 24th Ward Alderman Jacob M. Arvey (seated right). In 1974, after four decades as an alderman on Chicago's City Council, Keane was convicted of mail fraud and conspiracy. Arvey wielded significant political clout as a leader of the Chicago Democratic party.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of Central Manufacturing District, 1935
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Central Manufacturing District, looking northwest from a window in the Westinghouse plant on Pershing Road.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edward Brennan, 1926
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edward Brennan claimed never to have personally profited from his work on the reform of Chicago's addresses. His efforts were recognized in a resolution of the City Council on April 21, 1937. When Edward Brennan died in 1942, not only had the city been renumbered, but also at his urging the City Council had changed hundreds of street names. Brennan did not succeed in winning implementation for every aspect of his vision. For example, designations of Street, Avenue, and Road continued to be used randomly instead of being assigned to east-west, north-south, and diagonal streets respectivelybut his overall plan still makes life easier for every Chicago resident and visitor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edward Brennan Scrapbook, 1901
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Edward Brennan / Chicago Record Herald
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brennan began his renumbering campaign in the summer of 1901, as he recorded in a scrapbook of newspaper clippings.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Existing and Proposed Highways in the Metropolitan Region, c.1926
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Regional Planning Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1926, the Chicago Regional Planning Association published a study of Highways in the Region of Chicago, concluding, "The one cure for traffic congestion is to build wider roads and more of them." A sketch map included in the booklet showed "paved highways" and "suggested pavement." Instead of a grid, the overall pattern is one of spokes of a wheel.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Herbert Brown to Edward Brennan, 1934
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Herbert Brown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brennan acted as chair of the Subcommittee on Street Numbers and Signs at the City Club, which actively campaigned for the elimination of duplicate street names and posting of clear signage. Among the items saved in Brennan's scrapbooks are a number of letters from companies ranging from Western Union and Marshall Field's department store to Riddiford Brothers Janitors' Supplies, supporting the plan to eliminate duplicate street names. After the second major renaming initiative in 1936, the proceedings of the Chicago City Council for April 21, 1937, proudly noted, "[T]here are now only 1363 street names in Chicago for 3624 miles of streets. . . . There are now fewer street names in Chicago than in any other city in the country of even one-half the area of Chicago."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Southwest Chicago, 1955
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Transit Authority
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The photograph taken in 1955 of a square-mile section of Chicago (Cicero Avenue on the west, Pulaski Street on the east, 79th Street on the north, and 87th Street on the south) shows the beginnings of development. A curvilinear layout empties into Scottsdale Shopping Center, still under construction at the time. A <emph>Tribune</emph> article from May 18, 1953, announced that the future shopping center would "be an integral part" of the Raymond T. Lutgert Construction Company's 120-acre development.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Southwest Chicago, 1962
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Transit Authority
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By 1962, most of the area had filled in. The remainder of the upper portion of the area is filled with curvilinear streets, although the streets are closer together and the lot sizes smaller. The remainder of this square mile has Chicago's traditionally straight streets. Visible landmarks include Bogan High School and Bogan Park at the southeast corner of 79th and Pulaski Streets and a portion of St. Mary's Cemetery at the southeast corner of 87th and Pulaski Streets. The undeveloped areas at the southwest corner of 79th and Pulaski Streets and the large open area at the northeast corner of Cicero Avenue and 87th Street have filled in since 1962 with grid-style development.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Main Branch of Chicago River, 1951
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The curve of the river dictates the form of Wacker Drive, the only street in the city that has addresses with directionals for north, south, east, and west. In this photo looking east along the main branch of the Chicago River, Wacker Drive can be seen as it follows the south shore of the main branch before turning south at Wolf Point (in the lower left corner of the photo) to follow the east bank of the river's South Branch. The double-decked Wacker Drive, completed in 1926, initially extended west and south to Lake Street, where it became Market Street. In 1953, the City Council changed the name of Market Street to South Wacker Drive.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Highway Map of Cook County, 1970
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Department of Public Works and Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By 1970, the interstate highway system was well-established. Major highways can be seen snaking through the landscape seemingly without regard to the grid, though the entrances and exits remain tied to major roads, many of which sit on old township lines.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Surveying Equipment of James Thompson, 1830
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Canal Commissioners hired James Thompson, a surveyor from Kaskaskia in downstate Randolph County, to create Chicago's first plat (or map showing proposed lots) in 1830. He laid out the town with straight streets uniformly 66 feet wide (the length of a surveyor's chain) with alleys 16 feet wide bisecting each block.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thompson's Plat of 1830
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: James Thompson
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Near North Side, Near West Side, Loop

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Main Branch of Chicago River and Harbor, 1950
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Herald American

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Graham Taylor at Chicago Commons Settlement House, 1924
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Modeled on Hull House, Chicago Commons was founded in 1894 by Graham Taylor, seen here presiding over a flagpole dedication at the settlement house's Grand Avenue building (955 W. Grand) in 1924.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Warren G. Harding in Chicago, 1920
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Republican candidate for President, Warren G. Harding, stands with Ohio Governor Frank Bartlett and an unidentified man at the Republican Convention in Chicago, where the "smoke-filled room" meeting took place, 1920.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glenview Naval Air Station, 1951
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Official U. S. Marine Corps Department of Defense Photo

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Who is Balbo?," 1933
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creators: Italian Socialist League, Italian League for the Rights of Man
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Italo Balbo, the namesake of Balbo Avenue in Chicago's south Loop, was a fascist party leader and close associate of dictator Benito Mussolini. As Mussolini's Ministry of Air, Balbo attracted worldwide attention by leading the Italian Formation Flight from Rome to Chicago during the World's Fair of 1933. Upon his arrival in Chicago, Balbo and his Italian flying unit were received as dignitaries and a street was named in his honor to commemorate the visit. As this broadside printed by the Italian Socialist Federation and the Italian League for the Rights of Man indicates, not everyone in the city welcomed the pilot so warmly.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago, North Shore & Milwaukee Railway Advertisement, 1922
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Printer: Edwards & Deutsch Litho. Co.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago, Rock Island, & Pacific Railroad Advertisement, 1886
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Printer: J. M. W. Jones Stationery and Printing Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Starting with a single rail links between Chicago and Rock Island, the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad became the first to bridge the Mississippi, encouraging western settlement via their lines, as in this broadside.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pamphlet issued by Juvenile Protective Association of Chicago, 1916
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: Edith Abbott
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of the campaigns waged by the Juvenile Protective Association of Chicago in the early twentieth century was to reform the correction system in the state, particularly the county jails.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Garment Industry Sweatshop at 132 Maxwell Street, 1905
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Employees in Chicago Laundry, 1903
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Young female laundry workers, seen here in 1903, participated in a city-wide laundry strike.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mabel Vernon Addressing Crowd at Van Buren Street and Michigan Avenue, 1916
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From the late 1860s until 1920, advocates of women's suffrage gave numerous public speeches to champion women's right to vote. In 1916 suffragist Mabel Vernon addressed a crowd at the intersection of Van Buren Street and Michigan Avenue.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Van Buren St. and Michigan Ave.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago State Hospital, 1947
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By the mid-twentieth century, the facilities at the Chicago State Hospital (then commonly known as Dunning Asylum) were outdated and overcrowded. Few of the buildings had been updated since its rebuilding after a fire in 1910. This photo, taken in February 1947, reveals the poorly ventilated, narrow, and congested hallways in which some patients slept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Irving Park Rd. and Narragansett Ave.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Legal Aid Society Offices, c.1910
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Charles J. Bernauer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Legal Aid Society established in 1905, from a merger of the Productive Agency for Women and Children and the Legal Aid Bureau, provided free legal services to men, women, and children in need.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Alta M. Hulett, c.1873
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Gentile
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1873, nineteen year old Alta Hulett became the first woman admitted to the Illinois bar.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Construction of Wacker Drive, 1925
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Architectural Photographic Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1925 the Great Lakes Dredge and Dock Company worked at the intersection of South Water Street and Wabash Avenue to create the bi-level Wacker Drive.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bughouse Square, 1993
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: John McCarthy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the annual Bughouse Square Festival at Washington Park in the Near North Side, participants follow a tradition of public speaking at this location that dates back to World War I. The festival, sponsored by the Newberry Library, includes reinactments of speeches by famous Chicagoans and, as shown here at this 1993 event, stages for the public to participate in soapbox oratory, music, and poetry presentations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Merchandise Mart, 1949
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Earl Fiske
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A boat passes under the Wells Street bridge on the Chicago River in front of the Merchandise Mart in the summer of 1949.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Metra North Western Station (Ogilvie Transportation Center), 1988
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: John McCarthy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Looking south from Lake Street "L" station toward the Metra Northwestern Station and Office Building (Ogilvie Transportation Center), 1988

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nobel Prize Certificate awarded to Jane Addams, 1931
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: Nobel Committee of the Norwegian Parliament

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Topsy Turvy Times Display, 1926
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A window display at the Chicago Daily News building at 400 W. Madison Street featured a model set for the Topsy Turvy Time children's contest show. WMAQ radio personality Russell Pratt is depicted playing the piano for two children. WMAQ gave away prizes and Topsy Turvy Time diplomas to children who won contests aired during the show.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago Sun-Times / Chicago Daily News building, 1964
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Hutchinson Photography
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chicago Sun-Times / Chicago Daily News building, 1964

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bird's-Eye View of 63rd and Halsted Streets, 1948
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Richard M Stevens

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Men's Dormitory Beds at Pacific Garden Mission, 1980
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Kathleen Collins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Neatly made men's dormitory beds at Pacific Garden Mission on 646 S. State Street, 1980

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woodlawn Boy Bandits, 1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woodlawn Boy Bandits, 1907

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Third Annual Charlie Parker Memorial Jazz Concert, 1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joe Segal began his career booking bands for Roosevelt University in 1947. By the 1950s, he had become one of the premiere figures in the Chicago jazz scene, hosting shows in venues throughout the city, including the C&C Lounge, which held an annual memorial concert in honor of jazz great Charlie Parker beginning in 1955 on the day of Parker's death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Conference, 1944
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1944 the NAACP held a conference in Chicago. Among the dignitaries present was Chicago alderman Earl B. Dickerson (front row to the left of woman in black hat).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Milwaukee Avenue in Niles, 1913
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Milwaukee Avenue north of Touhy Avenue was the central business area of Niles, when the city was incorporated in 1899.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Norwegian Constitution Day, 1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Children in Chicago celebrate Norwegian Constitution Day on May 17, 1907.
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Leavitt St. and North, west to Humboldt Park

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Limestone Quarry near Joliet Penitentiary, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Prisoners from the Illinois state penitentiary in Joliet worked in the limestone quarries located next to the prison (seen in the background of this photograph, likely taken around the turn of the twentieth century).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poster Depicting "$acred Motherhood," 1908
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Artist: Luther Bradley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "$acred Motherhood" was created in 1908 by <emph>Chicago Daily News</emph> cartoonist Luther Bradley for exhibition at a joint conference of the Women's Trade Union League and the Chicago Federation of Labor. Simultaneously calling for a shorter work day for woman and implicating working conditions in the garment manufacturing industry, the poster portrays a haggard and overworked mother attempting to combine domestic and factory duties with dismal and chaotic results.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William R. Plumb and Lilacs, 1926
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William R. Plumb stands next to a lilac tree in his garden in Lombard in 1926.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Members of the Anti-Saloon League, 1910
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Anti-Saloon League pose with a petition submitted in 1910 demanding that the local option question -- whether a community could opt to prohibit the distribution of liquor licenses in its boundaries -- be submitted to the voters of Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Union Stock Yard Co., c.1910
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In addition to polluting the waterways and creating a noxious stench, the fertilizer and meat-packing plants of the Union Stock Yards also emitted smoke and other pollutants into air.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Win Stracke and Ray Tate at Old Town School of Folk Music, c.1970s
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Win Stracke (left) began his folk singing career in Chicago in 1931. Working with his friend and radio personality Studs Terkel, Stracke used his music to promote and assist the labor movement of the mid-twentieth century. In 1957, intending to improve his own skills as a guitar player, Stracke joined with Dawn Greening to found the Old Town School of Folk Music and then began its first director. Stracke is shown here with Ray Tate, the School's second director, in front of Old Town's second home at 909 W. Armitage Avenue, acquired in 1968 when its original building at 333 W. North Avenue was demolished. Tate served as director from 1971 to 1981. Stracke continued to perform and support the school until his death in 1991.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Anniversary Celebration for Olivet Baptist Church, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Oscar B. Willis & Associates
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1952 Reverend Joseph Harrison Jackson and his wife celebrated their 25th wedding anniversary and the 102nd anniversary of Olivet Baptist Church. According to church publications, under Dr. Jackson's pastorship, which lasted from 1941 to his death in 1990, church membership rose to exceed 20,000 parishioners before declining during the 1960s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Treaty of Greenville (written draft), 1795
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creators: Various
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Greenville Treaty set into motion a process which led DuSable to sell his Chicago holdings. Until then, Indian treaties with Great Britain and the United States had set the Ohio River as the boundary between areas of whit and Indian settlement. Following Anthony Wayne's 1794 victory at the Battle of Fallen timbers, Indians ceded over two-thirds of southern and eastern Ohio. In addition, they ceded "one piece of land six miles square at the mouth of the Chikago river, emptying into the south-west end of Lake Michigan, where a fort formerly stood." Within a decade, Fort Dearborn had been established.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Kennison marker in Lincoln Park, 1903
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Kennison arrived in Chicago in the 1840s as an old man. He was a veteran of the War of 1812, but became a local celebrity by falsely claiming to be the last survivor of the Boston Tea Party and a veteran of the Revolution. Though historians have established that he was approximately 85 years old when he died in 1852, Chicagoans believed he was 115, and buried him with the pomp they thought was owed to the last survivor of the Tea Party. In 1903 aging Chicagoans who still remembered the 1850s erected a monument to Kennison at his gravesite in Lincoln Park. Even in the age of the Internet the official city Web site has presented Kennison's story as fact.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Monument to Stephen A. Douglas, 1928
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Even when historical memory fades, monuments and markers may persist in the landscape to claim attention. Stephen Douglas was one of the most powerful political leaders of the 1850s, foremost proponent of a policy intended to avert civil war over slavery. After his death in 1861, his landholdings on the south side became the site of a prison camp named for him. Decades later his friends sponsored a monument designed by Leonard Volk at his tomb near 35th Street. The monument has persisted in an area that became a Jewish neighborhood and later a center of African American life and culture. Douglas was neither an abolitionist nor a proponent of slavery, and in the 21st century his monument is easier to recognize than his legacy. His doctrine of popular sovereignty rested on a faith in the power of mobility; the Illinois Central Railroad that he helped bring to Chicago brought many descendants of freed people to Chicago in the century after his death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Official World's Fair Weekly, "Chicago's First Citizen," 1933
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Author: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1933 Century of Progress Exposition boosted popular memory of DuSable by exhibiting a replica of DuSable's cabin as it had been envisioned in the 1884 engraving in A. T. Andreas's <emph>History of Chicago</emph>. While the replica was just 8 feet by 12 feet, the record of the sale of the house in 1800 indicates that its area was actually nine times larger, although imagining a tiny, rustic log cabin better serves the narrative of dramatic progress. DuSable's status in Chicago's past took on new significance in the 20th century, as Chicago became a center of African American culture and could look back with pride at the role of a black businessman in the city's origin story.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chief Blackhorn and Italo Balbo, 1933
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
At the 1933 Century of Progress Exposition, Chicagoans looked back at the past as a way of celebrating progress and anticipating the future. To advertise its own modernizing vigor, Fascist Italy sent a squadron of twenty-four seaplanes under the command of Italo Balbo, the Minister of Aviation, on a transatlantic flight to Chicago. When Balbo arrived on July 15, 1933, the city enthusiastically greeted him as a second Lindbergh, renaming 7th Street for him. It later installed an ancient Roman column uprooted from Ostia, a gift of Fascist Italy to commemorate Balbo's flight, on the fair grounds near Soldier Field.
In what was perhaps part of a complex imperial imagination of American antiquities, Sioux participants of the Fair's Indian Village adopted Balbo as "Chief Flying Eagle." Chief Blackhorn presented Balbo with a headdress, while Balbo in turn presented the chief with a Fascist medallion pendant.
Though Balbo Drive and the Roman column persist, along with muted awareness of Balbo's visit, memory of the warmth with which Chicagoans welcomed a Fascist General has been too embarrassing to sustain in detail since World War II.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reproduction of Fort Dearborn at the Century of Progress Exposition, 1933
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Kaufmann & Fabry Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Visitors to the 1933 Century of Progress Exposition could measure Chicago's progress by walking through a replica of Fort Dearborn. In the midst of displays representing manufacturers, industrial processes, and the cultures and nations of the world, visitors could engage Chicago's history by becoming tourists of a reconstruction of a mythic part of it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sign in Bullpen Door at Comiskey Park, 1991
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Melody Miller
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By the time of the demise of the original Comiskey Park in 1991, baseball fans had had more than 80 years to attach to the site their memories of parents and friends, of hot dogs, sunny afternoons, and favorite players. By persisting through time, places like Comiskey can become monuments of a sort, meaningful because of past events and not solely because of their present uses. Yet present uses may conflict with the role of serving as a repository of memories. The new Comiskey Park opened across the street from the old one in 1991, and in 2003 the name itself became a matter of memory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lincoln Room, Chicago Historical Society, 1931
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Institutions such as the Chicago Historical Society have had a dual mission to serve both history and memory—to preserve the evidence of history and support research, and also to educate the public and help shape civic memory. Although Abraham Lincoln was not a Chicago resident, the Historical Society has a significant collection of Lincoln-related papers and artifacts, and has interpreted these materials in many displays since the 1870s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New Mt. Hermon M. B. Church, 1975
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: J. G. Domin
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Before there were any church buildings in Chicago, small groups met in private homes and vacant spaces, and some new congregations have continued to begin in this way. Some groups have rented or borrowed space from an established church. Many congregations of small means have adapted spaces built for other purposes, such as vacant storefronts.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mandel Brothers Advertisement in <emph>New World</emph>, 1934
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: New World
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From the perspective of the secular world, one effect of religious practices and identities has been to define potential markets. Mandel Brothers, a downtown department store, took out a full-page ad in a 1934 publication of the Archdiocese of Chicago to announce the existence of private shopping accommodations for nuns. The practical needs of diverse faiths in Chicago have supported religious supply stores, bookstores, architects, stained glass artists, specialized sculptors and painters, and furniture suppliers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Scenes in a Camp Meeting in McHenry Co., Ill.," 1853
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Authors: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Methodist camp meetings in the 19th century could be raucous affairs, with emotional preaching and energetic expressions of worship in which verbal and physical behavior that would be unusual in ordinary life was felt to be a sign of the spirit of God. Such meetings thrived in areas of recent settlement, where many could have considered themselves "outsiders." To some, however, these ecstatic meetings were an opportunity for crowd-watching entertainment, and offered a way to define their own more sober style of religiosity by contrast.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: World Council of Churches, Program for Morning Service, 1954
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: World Council of Churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Second Assembly of the World Council of Churches drew 1,600 delegates and thousands of other Protestants to Evanston in 1954, six years after the first assembly in Amsterdam. Joseph H. Jackson, pastor of Olivet Baptist Church and president of the National Baptist Convention, was among the delegates from Protestant denominations around the world who gathered at Northwestern University's newly built McGaw Hall. A week before Jackson presided over the morning service, President Dwight D. Eisenhower had addressed the convocation. More than 125,000 people attended the opening ceremonies in Soldier Field, less than a month before 260,000 set an attendance record at the stadium's Roman Catholic Marian Year celebration.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Intercommunity Councils, 1963
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Northeastern Illinois Metropolitan Area Planning Commission
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the 1960s the Northeastern Illinois Planning Commission sought to foster cooperation between neighboring municipalities by encouraging the development of intercommunity councils, where representatives of local governments could deliberate on issues of common concern and attempt to coordinate regional planning. Similar councils exist in the early twenty-first century, including the South Suburban Mayors and Managers Association and the Barrington Area Council of Governments.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Replica of the Original Fort Dearborn," <emph>Chicago Tribune</emph>, 5 March 1899
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Tribune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1899, little more than 40 years after the second Fort Dearborn had been demolished, Chicago had a population of 1.6 million, and the landscape of the early nineteenth century had changed dramatically. The Chicago Historical Society in 1899 put on display a detailed replica of the original Fort Dearborn that had been destroyed in 1812.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Annuities Paid to Potawatomi Chiefs, 1827
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Alexander Wolcott
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alexander Wolcott's list of Potawatomi Chiefs to Whom Annuities Were Paid, 1827

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Planners in Daniel Burnham's Office, 1908
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seated around table from far left: Edward B. Butler, Daniel H. Burnham, Charles D. Norton, Clyde M. Carr, Edward F. Carry, Edward H. Bennett, John DeLaMater, Charles G. Dawes, Charles H. Wacker, John V. Farwell, John W. Scott, Emerson B. Tuttle, Theodore W. Robinson, Charles H. Thorne, John G. Shedd
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Burnham's office, in RRExchange Bldg, 200 block of S. Michigan Ave.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Diorama of Rush Street at the Chicago Historical Society, 1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Robert H. Harr, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When the Chicago Historical Society moved into its new building in Lincoln Park in 1931, curators intended to have no "permanent" exhibits, with the exception of eight dioramas portraying notable scenes and events in Chicago history. The dioramas have persisted, and are interesting today not only for their visualizations of early Chicago, but as artifacts indicating something about how Chicago history was interpreted in 1931.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Workers Walking near the Pullman Car Works, 1914
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State Street Subway Look South as a Northbound Train Approaches the Jackson-Van Buren Station, 1943
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Socialist, 1879
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Socialist
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Socialist Labor Party Eight-Hour Demonstration and Picnic, 1879

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Voting Records of Illinois Federal Legislators on Great Society Programs, 1965
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Chicago Democratic Party

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rendering for Sears Tower by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, 1971
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill (reproduced by Hedrich-Blessing)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chicago Academy of Sciences and Cafe Brauer, as seen from 2000 N. Lincoln Park West, 1964
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: William S. Engdahl, Hedrich-Blessing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chicago Academy of Sciences (right) and Café Brauer (left), 1964. Café Brauer was designed in 1908 by Prairie School architect Dwight Perkins. In 1989 the Lincoln Park Zoological Society in cooperation with the Chicago Park District and the Levy organization completed a $4.2 million renovation to restore the Café as a dining establishment, park facility, and historic landmark.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pioneering disc jockey Jack L. Cooper, 1954
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Graphic Photo Service, Inc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pioneering Chicago disc jockey Jack L. Cooper, in the WSBC studios at 2400 W. Madison, where he began playing records in 1931.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flutists in the Chicago Youth Symphony Orchestra, 1954
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: M. J. Schmidt

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harold Washington Library Center, c.1990
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: John McCarthy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The current main branch of Chicago's public library system, here shown under construction, opened in 1991, almost a century after the building it succeeded, which is now the Chicago Cultural Center, located on Michigan Avenue between Washington and Randolph Streets. The new library, designed by Hammond, Beeby and Babka, is situated at State Street and Congress Parkway, and was a significant step in the effort to rejuvenate the South Loop.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beginning of the 1919 Riot
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Unknown / Author: Chicago Commission on Race Relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Press Release by Senator Paul H. Douglas on Indiana Dunes, 1966
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Creator: U. S. Senator Paul H. Douglas
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Upon learning that the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore had moved one step closer toward authorization, Senator Paul Douglas issued a triumphant, if somewhat cautious, statement to the press.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Indoor Baseball Game, 1905
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photographer: Chicago Daily News
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Indoor baseball game in Chicago, between All Chicago and Illinois Central.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Chicago in 1831," in <emph>Wau-Bun</emph>, 1856
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Artist: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The predominant popular understanding of the 1812 Fort Dearborn conflict has been formed by Juliette Magill Kinzie's <emph>Wau-Bun: The Early Day in the Northwest</emph>, first published in 1856. <emph>Wau-Bun</emph> recounted Kinzie's experiences in Chicago from 1833 as well as Kinzie family stories heard from her mother-in-law. In the early 20th century historian Milo M. Quaife found Kinzie's account unreliable in its account of Fort Dearborn, as it relied on family stories that exaggerated the role of some participants and was unfairly biased against others. Over time Quaife came to realize that despite his findings, the literary appeal of Kinzie's book was likely to retain its power over the popular imagination of Chicagoans.
